journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Uncertainty in performance for linear and nonlinear energy harvesting strategies

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science, Duke University, Durham, NC, USA
2Department of Engineering Mathematics, University of Bristol, Bristol, UK

author-notes.corresp: Brian P Mann, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science, Duke University, 101 Hudson Hall, Durham, NC 27708, USA. Email: brian.mann@duke.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Topical Issue on Nonlinear Energy Harvesting

abstract.p: Vibrational energy harvesters are often linear mass–spring–damper-type devices, which have their resonant frequency tuned to the dominant vibration frequency of their host environment. As such, they can be highly sensitive to uncertainties, which may arise from the imprecise characterization of the host environment or, alternatively, from manufacturing defects and tolerances. It has previously been claimed that the use of nonlinear energy harvesters may be one way to alleviate the problems of these uncertainties. This article presents a systematic uncertainty propagation study of a prototypical electromagnetic energy harvester. More specifically, the response of a linear harvester in the presence of parametric uncertainty is compared to the response of harvesters containing some common forms of nonlinearity, that is, hardening, softening, or bistability. Analytical solutions are used in combination with presumed levels of parametric uncertainty to quantify the resulting uncertainty in the power output. Consequently, these studies can determine the regions in the parameter space where a nonlinear strategy may outperform a more traditional linear approach.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The success of portable electronics and remote sensing devices is dependent upon the availability of remote power. While batteries can sometimes fulfill this role over short time intervals, they are often undesirable due to their finite life span, need for replacement, and environmental impact. Instead, researchers are now investigating the methods of scavenging energy from the environment to eliminate the need for batteries or to prolong their life (Roundy et al., 2003). While solar, chemical, and thermal sources of energy transfer are sometimes viable, many have recognized the abundance of environmental disturbances that cause either rigid body motion or structural vibrations. This has led to a dramatic increase in the number of studies for vibration-based energy harvesting (Saha, 2006; Shahruz, 2006a, 2006b; Stephen, 2006; Yang et al., 2009; Yen and Lang, 2005).

While the research over the past decade has primarily focused on inertial generators that operate in a linear regime (Beeby et al., 2006, 2007; Horowitz et al., 2006; Leland and Wright, 2006; Lesieutre et al., 2004; Mann and Owens, 2010; Poulin et al., 2004; Renno et al., 2009; Roundy, 2005), recent work suggests that designing a harvester to operate in a nonlinear regime can improve the harvesters’ performance (Mann and Sims, 2009). More specifically, several research groups are now investigating the use of nonlinearities to extend the bandwidth, broaden the frequency spectrum, and/or to facilitate tuning (Barton et al., 2010; Cammarano et al., 2011; Challa et al., 2008; Erturk et al., 2009; Mann and Owens, 2010; Soliman et al., 2008; Stanton et al., 2009, 2010; Triplett and Quinn, 2009). These efforts take aim at overcoming the limitations of linear devices, which only perform well within a narrow band of frequencies (Mann and Sims, 2009).

The output power is one of the most important measures of performance. It is most often reported as the peak power, the average peak power, or the peak power divided by one or more quantities such as the volume or the base acceleration. Despite the fact that recent efforts have begun to question whether a linear or nonlinear strategy should be used, little to no work has appeared to quantify the effect that uncertainties in the physical parameters have on the uncertainty in the output power—especially for nonlinear systems (Ali et al., 2010). However, many sources of uncertainty exist, such as uncertainties in the lowest natural frequency, damping, excitation source, and physical dimensions that can dramatically alter the performance. This has motivated the authors to consider the question of whether a measure of robustness should accompany the typically reported values of peak performance.

The present article investigates how linear and nonlinear energy harvesting strategies are affected by uncertainties. Comparisons are made between a prototypical harvester—one that uses a linear oscillator and electromagnetic induction for energy conversion—and the same system with different types of nonlinear restoring forces. The dimensionless equations are used for each of these systems to generalize the results that elucidate which types of strategies are more robust to uncertainty.

The content of this article is organized as follows. The next section derives and nondimensionalizes the mathematical model under the consideration of a generic restoring force. Approximate analytical solutions are then used to obtain the frequency response of the system for various types of restoring forces. In particular, we derive approximate analytical solutions for the frequency response and average power delivered to an electrical load for the following types of restoring forces: (a) linear, (b) a cubic polynomial representation of hardening and softening springs, and (c) a cubic polynomial representation of a bistable spring. The responses of these systems are then compared for the case when all the system and excitation parameters are precisely known; this is followed by a section that uses uncertainty propagation to explore the robustness of the power output for each type of restoring force. The article concludes by discussing the implications of the uncertainty plots for harvesters with spatial constraints and describes the additional considerations that must be taken into account if a nonlinear harvester is pursued.

sec.title: Energy harvester model
sec.p: This section derives the dimensionless equations that govern the behavior of the harvesters under consideration. Since the goal is to consider a prototypical device that uses electromagnetic induction for energy conversion (see Figure 1), the final governing equations are reminiscent of the equations given in Beeby et al. (2007), Mann and Owens (2010), and Sari et al. (2008). However, we present an energy-based derivation and use a generic function for the restoring forces to aid in the analyses that follow.

caption.p: Illustration of a prototypical energy harvester that uses electromagnetic induction for energy conversion. Illustration (a) shows the oscillating magnet with a nonlinear restoring force and linear viscous damping, whereas (b) shows the schematic for the electrical circuit.

caption.p: Illustrations of the potential energy (left column) and corresponding restoring forces (right column) considered in the present study. Starting with the top row and progressing to the bottom row, the graphs show linear (a) and (b), hardening (c) and (d), softening (e) and (f), and bistable (g) and (h) potential energy curves and restoring forces.

sec.p: In the analyses that follow, the frequency response for equations (6) and (8) will be derived for each type of restoring force. The amplitude of the responses, along with the average power delivered to an electrical load, is then compared for the nominal case. Subsequently, the uncertainty in the power output is determined with respect to uncertainty in the physical parameters, thus revealing which types of restoring force are robust, for example, to manufacturing errors.

sec.title: Theoretical analysis
sec.p:
This section derives the frequency responses of the mechanical and electrical systems to compare the average power harvested. To make these comparisons, an expression for the average power is formed by integrating the dimensionless form of the instantaneous power
P = ρ
I
2
over the period of the excitation

where
T = 2 π / η
is the period of the excitation source. Although this expression assumes an ideal transducer, where the internal resistance is zero,
R
i
= 0
, there is no loss of generality since the actual power delivered to the resistive load would augment all the cases studied by approximately the same fraction.

sec.title: Bistable harvester analysis
sec.p: The dimensionless equation for a bistable oscillator that is coupled to the aforementioned electrical circuit is

where
β
is a dimensionless constant for the bistable system. Unlike the systems already examined, the bistable case has multiple stable equilibria, which are located at
y
e
= ± ( 1 / β
)
2
when
β > 0
. We therefore expect that small levels of excitation will cause relatively small oscillations around one of the stable equilibria. However, past research on bistable mechanical oscillators has shown a dramatic increase in the energy level of the response once exceeding the threshold for a potential well escape (Virgin, 2000).

The approximate analytical solution can be derived by assuming a solution in the form of a truncated Fourier series with time-varying coefficients,

sec.title: Comparison of response trends
sec.p: This section compares the frequency and average power responses of the linear, hardening, softening, and bistable harvesters. While the results of this section only consider the ideal case, when there is no parameter uncertainty, the next section will focus on the additional considerations that arise due to parameter uncertainty.

Figures 3 to 6 show a series of response trends for each of the systems considered. Starting with the response trends of the linear system, which are shown in Figure 3, it is evident that both the amplitude of the mechanical oscillator’s response and the average power peak near, albeit not exactly at, the natural frequency (Mann and Owens, 2010). In addition, the average power scales with the square of
Γ
and a single maximum appears in the
ρ
versus
P
a
plot of Figure 3(d).

sec.p:
Responses from the system with a hardening nonlinearity are shown in Figure 4. These results reveal a bending of the frequency response to the right with
P
a
values similar to those of the linear system. The plot of
Γ
versus
P
a
shows that this system exhibits a very different scaling behavior than the linear system; for example, a bifurcation in the response can cause a sudden increase or decrease in
P
a
near
Γ ≈ 0 . 3
and
Γ ≈ 0 . 1
. The
ρ
versus
P
a
plot of Figure 4(d) also displays an interesting behavior since more than one local maxima exist.

Responses from the system with a softening nonlinearity are shown in Figure 5. These results reveal a bending of the frequency response to the left with peak amplitudes only slightly smaller than the linear system. As in the case of the hardening system, the
Γ
versus
P
a
plot shows that the response of the system does not scale linearly. Similar to the hardening system, the softening system contains multiple local maxima in the
ρ
versus
P
a
.

The last set of response trends, which were created for the bistable system, is shown in Figure 6. In contrast to all the other systems studied, one noticeable difference for the bistable system is the emergence of additional solution branches. More specifically, these solutions are associated with the oscillations within a single potential well and those that cross the center potential well barrier shown in Figure 2(g). This system can exhibit similar
P
a
values to those of the linear system, but, as in the case of the softening and hardening system, displays more complex scaling in its response behavior as
Γ
is increased. In addition, the plots of
ρ
versus
P
a
show that the system can have even more local maxima.

Before discussing the advantages and disadvantages of the behavior displayed by each system, the results of the uncertainty analysis, which is the topic of section “Uncertainty analysis and constraints,” are first discussed.

sec.title: Uncertainty analysis and constraints
sec.p: The previous section derived analytical solutions for the frequency responses of the ideal cases, that is, when there is no uncertainty associated with the model parameters or with the excitation source. The aim of this section is take a closer step toward reality and consider how the performance of each harvester fairs when there is some uncertainty associated with the response of the system.
To explain the uncertainty propagation process, consider the case of a solution that is defined by the general expression

which is a function of
N
variables denoted by
(
x
1
,… ,
x
N
)
, where these variables are typically physical parameters. A perturbation
(
ϵ
1
,… ,
ϵ
N
)
representing the uncertainty is added to each of the variables, where each
ϵ
i
is assumed to be an independent normally distributed random variable with mean zero. Thus, the solution (with uncertainty) is now defined by

To achieve an analytically tractable result, the resulting solution is also assumed to be normally distributed (Coleman and Steele, 1999). In practice, this will not be the case, but, provided the perturbation is small, it will provide a good approximation (Coleman and Steele, 1999). To achieve a more precise quantification of the uncertainty in the solution, a numerical method such as generalized polynomial chaos should be used (Xiu and Karniadakis, 2002).

Since
f
is presumed to be normally distributed, all that is needed is to find the mean and variance of
f
as given by

where
E
is the expectation operator. After expanding
f
in a multivariate Taylor series expansion with respect to
ϵ
i
, equations (28) and (29) become

since the expectation operator is linear in terms of its arguments (Coleman and Steele, 1999), that is, the higher order terms have been dropped. Thus, the total uncertainty in the solution,
U
f
, at a desired confidence level is given by

where each
U
x
i
represents the uncertainty in the variable
x
i
at the same confidence level. It is common to express the uncertainty at the 95% confidence level (or 20:1 odds) and, consequently, 95% of the physical realizations can be expected to lie within the bounds calculated.

For the case of the linear system, equation (32) can be directly applied to equation (19) since the expression for
r
~
(see equation (17)) is explicitly defined. For the case of each nonlinear system, the derivatives are somewhat more difficult and implicit differentiation is required to obtain the derivatives.

Figures 9 and 10 show the nominal
P
a
responses for each system and the associated confidence intervals. The confidence intervals were obtained by first determining the uncertainty in the dimensionless average power
U
P
a
; next, the upper and lower confidence intervals were determined from

where
P
u
is the upper confidence interval and
P
l
is the lower confidence interval. In essence, the confidence intervals provide a measure of the robustness in the response of the system when parameter uncertainty is considered.

sec.title: Discussion of uncertainty propagation results
sec.p:
Figures 7 to 10 provide several examples of propagating uncertainty in one or more parameters to unveil the robustness of the each type of restoring force on the dimensionless average power. Focusing on the trends shown in Figures 7 to 9, the lack of robustness for the linear system, where the goal is to typically match the oscillator’s natural frequency to a dominant frequency in the environment, is revealed by the large difference between
P
u
and
P
l
near the peak operating point.

sec.p:
For all the nonlinear systems, only the stable periodic solutions are shown since these are the only physically realizable responses that could be observed experimentally. We also note that each of the nonlinear systems has a shared behavior whereby the confidence intervals go to infinity near a fold point in the system’s response; this is related to the fact that for some parameter choices near the fold point, the periodic orbit does not exist. However, in general, the lower bound for the expected system’s response is noticeably higher for the nonlinear systems. In addition, the size of the confidence interval
P
u
to
P
l
is smaller for many of the nonlinear cases, for example, see the bistable system response in Figure 9(d) as one of the best examples of
P
u
and
P
l
being very close to the nominal response. This demonstrates that the bistable system can provide a more robust response and nearly equivalent peak power than the more traditional result given by the linear system. As a point of clarity, we note that only the large-amplitude response has been shown in Figures 9(d) and 10(d) since the small-amplitude response is not of interest for energy harvesting purposes.

Figure 10 shows the trends in
P
a
,
P
u
, and
P
l
as the dimensionless level of excitation is varied. As in the results of Figure 9, the confidence intervals go to infinity near a fold point in the response behavior, and only the stable periodic solutions have been shown. These series of plots clearly indicate that the nominal (average) response of the linear system is much larger over most of the parameter space shown; however, for nonlinear systems, the spread or difference between
P
u
and
P
l
is much smaller and the lower bound on the confidence interval is considerably more favorable than that of the linear system. Furthermore, the response amplitude for the nonlinear oscillators reveals that the nonlinear systems could provide a more robust harvester when a limitation is imposed on the amplitude of the motion, that is, as in the case of a spatial constraint. We believe that this result is rather intuitive since more energy can be stored in a nonlinear spring than a linear spring over the same displacement amplitude.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presented a systematic study of the uncertainty in the average power delivered to an electrical load for linear and nonlinear harvesters alike. The study was motivated by recent observations that a linear harvester requires precise frequency tuning and recent claims in the literature that stated that nonlinear behavior could be used to improve the response characteristics, for example, broaden the frequency response. During this investigation, analytical solutions were derived for the response amplitude and power output for each type of restoring force. Additionally, in order to quantify the robustness of the response, we propagated presumed levels of uncertainty in the system parameters and the environmental excitation to calculate the output power over the 95% confidence interval. This allows for a systematic comparison of the advantages and disadvantages of different energy harvesters and, furthermore, it enabled us to determine the regions in the parameter space where a nonlinear strategy would outperform a more traditional linear approach and vice versa. However, in this uncertainty analysis, the coexistence of high- and low-energy solutions in the nonlinear systems and the dependence on initial conditions are not taken into account; at this time, it is not clear how these factors can be incorporated and this is an avenue for further research. Related to this is the uncertainty tending toward infinity close to a fold point in the system response; the nonexistence of periodic orbits for certain parameter values also makes the interpretation of the results more difficult.

An obvious extension to this work would be to look at the uncertainty propagation through the underlying physical parameters associated with actual design and manufacture of energy harvesters, for example, the uncertainty in the magnetic field strength of an off-the-shelf permanent magnet. It may well be that such sources of uncertainty lead to large uncertainties in mechanical characteristics, beyond what has been considered here. Conversely, it may become readily apparent that some sources of uncertainty are of little importance to the overall response, thus enabling manufacturing constraints to be relaxed. Overall, there is much to be gained from uncertainty analysis becoming more commonplace, particularly in the field of energy harvesting.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors B.P. Mann and B.A.M. Owens were financially supported by the Army Research Office and program manager Dr Ronald Joslin from the Office of Naval Research. D.A.W. Barton was financially supported by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council under grant EP/H018107/1.
